text: on the Hungarian frontier with Serbia it
feels as if a great fortress is being
defended from the refugees and migrants
who would make Europe their home they
repeat the refrain I've heard on the
migrant trail for years now I want to do
a better life because I've got a son as
war and Taliban lots of guys Syed and
his wife were lucky they made it this
far before borders further cells started
to close such a change from a year ago
now you can see people streaming towards
us across the fields and I can hear men
the cries of children all moving towards
this border the figures tell the story
last October 211,000 landed in the
Balkans this month so far under 2000 I
was here a year ago to witness this
fence going up that moment which
symbolized what you might call the start
of hard Europe politicians across
Western Europe have been since then
trying to stem mass migration it has
become one of the great defining
political themes of our age in Budapest
the government has rejected refugee
quotas Hungary recasting itself as the
defender of European Christian
civilization
and of a new continent what camps like
Calais will never be allowed again first
thing protect the borders everything gas
comes out there so Schengen as we have
announced it many times cannot be
defended from within Kali cannot be
sorted out until you're not able to
defend your borders in the south and in
the east we followed the migrant trail
up through Austria into Bavaria where
history's shade looms over the present
Hitler had a headquarters and holiday
home at Berchtesgaden and when he was
defeated thousands of Jewish survivors
were housed in temporary camps nearby
that legacy profoundly shaped Germany's
initial welcome for refugees fleeing
today's Wars there are around 1,000
living in this area they're fortunate
Germany too began to impose strict
border controls last year amar is from
Syria and is the houseguest of Marietta
Sulak who runs this health store while
public opinion has shifted Amara still
finds Germans tolerant they always want
to help you and I love to stay here I
used to live here it's nice to live with
him but I do set limits some things he
has to learn how Germans live and what
we like in Europe but political momentum
is with those opposed to asylum seekers
the far-right has gained votes by
promising a crackdown like this grandson
of a German wartime refugee dear didn't
the people are upset upset because of
the government decisions there are many
people who say we will not ask we want
to be asked if such important decisions
are made they're questioning the cost of
this
by the time I reached Calais with the
British Shore in view the political mood
in Europe was vividly clear in the
nearby jungle people were already moving
most of them single young men ahead of
the camp's demolition this Iraqi family
has been here six weeks but will soon be
moved elsewhere in France they want to
reach Britain we are only thinking of
going there there is no other country in
our minds we don't want to go anywhere
else
for the sake of our children's futures
closing the jungle won't deal with the
problem that simply disperses it and in
Africa the Middle East large parts of
Asia there are vast numbers of people
who believe that getting to Europe is
their best hope of a better life
as long as conflicts and endemic poverty
in these parts of the world continue
then however harder line Europe takes it
won't be enough to stem the flow of
refugees and migrants
frugal King BBC News Calais
